cards.explanation: We need to [...] the authentication system before deployment.
cards.short_meaning: to find and remove errors from computer code
cards.full_meaning:
Definition: To search for and eliminate malfunctioning elements or errors in computer hardware or software.

Examples:
• The developer spent hours debugging the memory leak.
• Always debug your code before pushing to production.

Synonyms: troubleshoot, fix, repair
Related: debugger (n), debugging (n)

cards.explanation: The team will [...] the new version to production servers tomorrow.
cards.short_meaning: to move software from development to production environment
cards.full_meaning:
Definition: To install, configure, and make software available for use in a production environment.

Examples:
• We deploy updates every Friday evening.
• The application was successfully deployed to AWS.

Collocations:
• deploy to production
• deployment pipeline
• continuous deployment

cards.explanation: Let's [...] this legacy codebase to improve maintainability and readability.
cards.short_meaning: to restructure code without changing its external behavior
cards.full_meaning:
Definition: The process of restructuring existing computer code without changing its external behavior, to improve nonfunctional attributes.

Examples:
• The code was refactored to follow SOLID principles.
• Refactoring helps reduce technical debt.

Benefits:
• Improved code readability
• Easier maintenance
• Better performance

cards.explanation: We should [...] the database queries to reduce the response time significantly.
cards.short_meaning: to make something as effective or functional as possible
cards.full_meaning:
Definition: To make a system, design, or decision as effective or functional as possible, especially regarding performance.

Examples:
• The algorithm was optimized to run in O(log n) time.
• Optimizing images can significantly improve page load speed.

Common uses:
• optimize performance
• optimize for speed
• code optimization

cards.explanation: The system architecture was designed with [...] in mind to handle millions of users.
cards.short_meaning: the capability of a system to handle growing amounts of work
cards.full_meaning:
Definition: The capability of a system, network, or process to handle a growing amount of work, or its potential to be enlarged to accommodate that growth.

Types:
• Horizontal scalability: adding more machines (scale out)
• Vertical scalability: adding more power to existing machines (scale up)

Examples:
• Cloud services provide excellent scalability.
• The database was chosen for its scalability features.
